title: Malacañang: NYT article on 'violent' Duterte a hack job
text:
Malacañang: NYT article on 'violent' Duterte a hack job By Audrey Morallo | Updated March 22, 2017 - 6:54pm Presidential spokesperson Ernesto Abella described a New York Times article on President Rodrigo Duterte as a "well-paid hack job." PPD/Released, File 
MANILA, Philippines — Malacañang on Wednesday gave a stinging rebuke to The New York Times after it published an article that chronicled President Rodrigo Duterte’s violence-marred rise to power, calling the story a “hack job” for people with “shady motives.” 
Ernesto Abella, the presidential spokesman, said that the newspaper seemed to be more interested in bullying governments with independent foreign policies than presenting the whole truth. 
“One gets the feeling NYT [New York Times] is not interested in presenting the whole truth, only that with which they can bully those who attempt an independent foreign policy,” said Abella, who famously called on journalists to use “ creative imagination ” to understand the pronouncements of Duterte. 
This is not the first time that Abella has criticized international media organizations for their coverage of the Duterte presidency. 
Earlier this month, he also criticized CNN for labeling the arrest of Sen. Leila De Lima on drug-related charges as "political persecution." 
In an article published on March 21, the New York Times published “Becoming Duterte: The Making of a Philippine Strongman” that narrated the president's rise from his elite childhood in Davao City to his election as its mayor and later to his capture of Malacañang.   
The article, written by Richard Paddock, told the story of the president’s anti-drugs crusade and his violent vision that the article alleged has been turned into a national policy. 
“The dissonance between the image of the gentle, caring grandfather and the brutal strongman spilling blood on the streets is just one of many in a common-man president who was born to the elite and has lived a life surrounded by violence,” the article said. 
Abella, without offering any evidence, insinuated that some moneyed individuals might be behind the article which he described as a “well-paid hack job.” 
"One would expect more from The New York Times," he said as he described the piece as a "well-paid hack job for well-heeled clients with shady motives." 
He said that the article “cynically and unfairly” narrated Duterte’s rise to power in the context of the article. 
Abella said that the chief executive did not engage in “western liberal niceties” to push forward his agenda of rebuilding the country. 
As an outsider, Duterte vowed to reduce poverty, address crime, corruption and illegal drugs and reinforce agreements with Muslim insurgents and communist rebels. 
He lamented that the author omitted in his story the projects the president made when he was still mayor of Davao City. 
“Davao City, under the leadership of President Duterte as mayor, is hailed as one of the safest cities in the world where residents follow an anti-smoking and a midnight alcohol ban,” he said, as he also enumerated some of Duterte’s initiatives as mayor such as Central 911, “Lingap Para sa Mahirap,” health assistance, free primary and secondary education in public schools and access to college education for poor students.
